intro: Loeflingia baetica, commonly known as the Baetica loeflingia, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the Iberian Peninsula. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils, often in dry, open habitats. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, and it is known for its limited distribution and ecological significance in Mediterranean ecosystems. Due to habitat loss and climate change, it is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts.
